dc:title: Salinity responses in two populations of viviparous Rhizophora mangle L. seedlings
dc:creator: Smith S.M.
dc:description: Viviparous seedlings of the red mangrove were collected from adult trees growing in areas of low (5‰) and high (36‰) surface water salinities, and planted as groups in large rectangular pots and treated with seawater corresponding to the two natural concentrations. Among individuals collected from the same site, growth was significantly enhanced in the low salinity treatment. Stem and leaf development exhibited larger differences between high and low salinities than did root growth. Propagules showed no increased capacity for growth when treated with salinities similar to the parent tree environments. Seedlings from the high salinity site exhibited faster growth than those from the low salinity site when treated with low salinity water, but differences between sites were insignificant in the high salinity treatment. -from Authors

dc:title: Competitive effects of three tropical tree species on two species of Piper
dc:creator: Gerwing J.
dc:description: Assessed relative understory suppression and intensity of root competition in year-old stands of Cordia alliodora, Hyeronima alchorneoides and Cedrela odorata by measuring the growth of seedlings of the pioneer tree Piper auritum and cuttings of the shade-tolerant shrub P. phytolaccaefolium that were planted into trenched and untrenched sites under the trees. After five months, growth of P. auritum was significantly less under Cordia and Hyeronima than under Cedrela or in the open. The most severe growth reductions occurred under Hyeronima, the species with the highest leaf area index (LAI). Lack of a significant trenching response under Hyeronima suggests the competitive effects of this species were largely the result of shading. The competitive effects of Cordia, a species with relatively high fine root density and open canopy, were almost entirely below ground. Nonetheless, the effects of Cordia and Hyeronima on growth of P. auritum seedlings were equivalent when compared on a per-unit of tree canopy LAI basis. Lack of P. auritum growth suppression under Cedrela is likely the result of the open canopies and relatively low fine root densities of the Cedrela stands. P. phytolaccaefolium growth did not differ among tree overstories. Among tree species, differences in morphology can lead to differences in understory suppression, but these differences depend upon the understory species. -from Author

dc:title: Annual patterns of litterfall in a lowland and tableland rainforest in tropical Australia
dc:creator: Stocker G.
dc:description: Fine litterfall (primarily leaves, twigs up to 1cm diameter, and reproductive parts) was collected weekly for five years in tropical rainforests at two contrasting sites (lowland and tableland) in North Queensland. Annual fine litterall (±95% confidence limits) was 8.00 ± 0.36 Mg ha-1 at the lowland site and 11.03 ± 0.47 Mg ha-1 at the tableland site. The range of annual fine litterfall was not great (7.04-8.74 Mg ha-1 at the lowland site; 10.02-13.64 Mg ha-1 on the tableland), but reproductive material varied substantially, both in absolute amount (0.85-1.86 and 1.41-4.74 Mg ha-1) and as a percentage of total litterfall for any year (12-21% and 14-35%) for lowland and tableland sites respectively. A seasonal maximum (October/November-hot dry season) was most evident for the old leaf component. Fruits and flowers were more irregularly spread through the year. The mean ratio of annual litterfall mass of reproductive material to leaves was 0.32. Fruit and flower mass in litter traps in tropical rainforest declines 50% every 10 days relative to leaf litter mass. -from Authors

dc:title: Density-dependent seed predation and plant dispersion of the tropical palm Normanbya normanbyi
dc:creator: Lott R.H.
dc:description: Adult black palm trees in the Cape Tribulation region, Queensland, occurred at a density of 20/ha. Their distribution was highly clumped and more than half the immature plants occurred within 3 m of an adult. Adult palms were also arranged in lines down the slope, apparently reflecting patterns of seed carriage by overland water flow. Seed dispersal is also affected by cassowaries Casuarius casuarius, a ratite which ranges over many hundreds of ha and deposits seeds in clusters. Small mammals which range over a few ha may deposit seeds as single entities (singletons). Many seeds remain undispersed beneath the female parent with heavy predation. Seeds were placed beneath adult trees at two densities and were dispersed over varying distances as clusters of ten seeds and as singletons. Pigs Sus scrofa and earwigs were the principal predators but they did not destroy all the seeds in any treatment. However, the germination percentage of the remaining seeds was greatly depressed indicating that one or both predators were disproportionately selecting potential germinants. Pigs were responsive to both density of seeds beneath a tree and the distance between seed sources; they did not damage dispersed seeds to a great extent. Earwigs also destroyed seeds more heavily beneath adult trees, but they were more efficient than pigs at locating dispersed seeds. Rodent predation was light and not responsive to seed density or dispersal. -from Authors

dc:title: Recruitment and decay of a pulse of Cecropia in Nicaraguan rain forest damaged by Hurricane Joan: relation to mutualism with Azteca ants
dc:creator: Ferguson B.
dc:description: In October 1988, Hurricane Joan severely damaged 500 000 ha of rain forest in SE Nicaragua. The forest is generally regenerating directly without passing through a secondary stage, but an apparent exception was the behaviour of Cecropia, a pioneer tree which experienced a dramatic pulse of recruitment in some areas. 1991 was the peak year of recruitment of Cecropia, but since then its pulse has decayed rapidly due to heavy mortality. The decline appears to be related to the unusually low rate of occupation by Cecropia's mutualistic Azteca ants: unoccupied trees had significantly higher mortality rates than occupied trees. -from Authors

dc:title: Structure and organic matter dynamics of a human-impacted pine forest in a MAB reserve of subtropical China
dc:creator: Brown S.
dc:description: A common practice by rural people in China is to harvest litter and understory from forests to meet their fuel needs. Determines the impact of this practice, occurring for over 40 yr, on the storages and flows of organic matter in a native pine forest in the Dinghushan Biosphere Reserve. Harvesting the net production of trees, with a replanting program, coupled with litter removal only provided the same quantity of organic matter, but was proposed as a more efficient method of fuel production because it would allow the soil organic matter, soil fertility, and tree regeneration to improve, while at the same time provide a higher quality fuel and reduce the time expended by women in fuel gathering. -from Authors

dc:title: Nutrient dynamics of a human-impacted pine forest in a MAB reserve of subtropical China
dc:creator: Jiangming Mo
dc:description: The effects of litter and understory harvesting by local people on the nutrient cycle in Pinus massoniana forest in Dinghushan Biosphere Reserve of subtropical China were studied by quantifying nutrient distribution, recycling, and loss in the ecosystem. The total nutrient standing stocks were 2066 kg ha-1 for N, 282 kg ha-1 for P, 541 kg ha-1 for K, 491 kg ha-1 for Ca, and 151 kg ha-1 for Mg. Most of these nutrients were contained in the top 10 cm of soil (72-94%). The total quantity of nutrients in the production of litterfall and understory were: 43.5 kg ha-1 yr-1 for N, 1.7 kg ha-1 yr-1 for P, 16.1 kg ha-1 yr-1 for K, 10.9 kg ha-1 yr-1 for Ca, and 2.7 kg ha-1 yr-1 for Mg. The harvest practice removed substantial quantities of these nutrients, 44-73% of the amount in litter and understory production, a rate that appeared to exceed most nutrient inputs from atmospheric deposition. The harvest practice also reduced the active soil organic matter pool thus reducing nutrient mineralization and soil nutrient availability. An alternative system of tree harvest and replanting, combined with litter removal only, was proposed that reduced by one-third or more the present nutrient removals. -Authors

dc:title: Diversification of Gulf/Caribbean mangrove communities through Cenozoic time
dc:creator: Graham A.
dc:description: Palynofloras from the early Eocene (c50 Ma) indicate that brackish-water coastal areas were occupied by four principal genera - Acrostichum, the extinct Brevitricolpites variabilis, Nypa, and Pelliceria (Pellicera). Avicennia is first reported in the late Miocene c10 Ma. Extinctions, introductions, and adaptations varied the composition and increased net diversity to six mangrove and three associated genera by the middle Pliocene (c3.5 Ma) - Acrostichum, Avicennia, Crenea, Laguncularia, Pelliceria, Rhizophora; Acacia, Hampea/Hibiscus, and Pachira. Modernization continued in the Quaternary with the first microfossils of Conocarpus, and with the addition of eight possible associates, for a total of 15 genera. Twelve others, unknown as fossils, were added during the Cenozoic to constitute the present-day community of c27 genera of mangroves and associates. The fossil record identifies a trend of increasing diversity that can be assessed as new assemblages are studied, and provides a first quantitative estimate of Neotropical history through the Cenozoic Era. -from Author

dc:title: Freshwater wetland plant communities of northern Belize: implications for paleoecological studies of Maya wetland agriculture
dc:creator: Rejmankova E.
dc:description: Sampling sites were located in the floodplains of the Rio Hondo and New River and within karstic depressions in the interfluves of the two rivers. Relationships among environmental variables and the occurrence of the individual marsh types, in particular those dominated by Cladium jamaicense, Eleocharis cellulosa, and Typha domingensis were investigated using canonical correspondence analysis. Eleocharis cellulosa marshes dominated areas with soil and water of high conductivity due to high content of gypsum and calcium carbonate. Nutrient concentrations, namely nitrogen and phosphorus, were very low. Conditions were rather similar in sawgrass marshes (Cladium jamaicense), except for higher water depth and lower conductivity. Marshes dominated by Typha domingensis occupied areas with higher content of nitrogen and phosphorus. Discriminant functions developed for these three marsh communities can be used to help interpret paleoecological data and infer ancient Maya impacts upon marsh development. -from Authors

dc:title: The abundance of insect herbivore species in the tropics: the high local richness of rare species
dc:creator: Price P.
dc:description: Local sampling of larval lepidopterans on Erythroxylum host plant species in tropical (Brazilian) savanna (cerrado) revealed a high species richness with low abundance per species. Cumulative numbers of morphospecies with increasing sampling effort yielded no asymptotic level of richness in sampling periods lasting six, seven and 23 months. Peak richness was reached at 31 species in 1992 and 19 species in 1993, on the three Erthyroxylum species sampled: E. deciduum, E. suberosum, and E. tortuosum. Less than one larvae was found per plant during all sampling times, with a mean of 0.28 species per plants in 1992 and 0.12 in 1993. The number of specimens of all species combined discovered per plant was very low at 0.10 per plant. Many plants remained unattacked on any sampling date with 12%, 8%, and 16% of plants attacked in the species listed in order above. In general, there was an increase in species found during the late dry season when new leaves were produced, but plant phenology seemed to exert only a small influence. Comparable temperate samples indicate a very different assemblage. Richness was from two to over three times higher in the tropics. Number of morphospecies per plant individual was similar at the sites, although total richness was lower in the temperate savanna. Number of total individuals per plants was 11-fold higher in the temperate samples; and the percent of plants with larvae present was over four times higher in the temperate zone (mean of 49%) than in the cerrado (12%). -from Authors

dc:title: Natural regeneration of Rhizophora mangle in strip clearcuts in northwest Ecuador
dc:creator: Blanchard J.
dc:description: In replicated 0.4 ha plots clearcut three years prior to the study, seedling densities were high within 5 m of seed trees, in plots surrounded by trees >25 cm DBH, and in plots frequently inundated by tides. Interstitial soil salinity (23.3-26.3 ppt) and litter cover were not correlated with seedling density. For natural regeneration to be sufficient for stand regeneration, logged areas should be no wider than 20 m and logging should be confined to forests with an average DBH >25 cm. In sites inundated by tides <20 times/month, seed trees should be retained at 20 m spacing. -from Authors

dc:title: Vegetation analysis, leaf structure and nutrient status of a Malaysian heath community
dc:creator: Turner I.M.
dc:description: A heath community found on Pulau Sibu, an island lying off the E coast of Peninsular Malaysia, consisted of a low scrub, generally <2 m in height, containing 24 species of vascular plants. It grew on a very shallow and acidic (pH 4.3) soil that was low in total nitrogen concentration (0.2%). Leaves of the 7 most common shrub species, Ixonanthes reticulata, Melastoma malabathricum, Rhodamnia cinerea, Rhodomyrtus tomentosa, Schima wallichii, Styphelia malayana and Tristaniopsis obovata, were collected. The community was characterized by very small leaves (a dominance of microphylls), with very low nitrogen, phosphorus and total chlorophyll concentrations, and chlorophyll a/b ratio. Lamina thickness, specific leaf area, crude fiber content and potassium concentrations were less extreme. A number of the species in the community are generally considered to be early successional, but no strong evidence could be found for any recent disturbance event that would have initiated the production of a seral community. -Authors

dc:title: Tree-epiphyte-ant relationships in the low inundated forest of Sian Ka'an Biosphere Reserve, Quintana Roo, Mexico
dc:creator: Dejean A.
dc:description: Research on epiphyte (9 bromeliads, 1 orchid) relationships with host trees, and with arthropods, especially ants, was undertaken. Epiphyte association with host trees is determined by the interaction of the epiphyte seed type and dispersal mode with the bark type of the host. Airborne seeds of Tillandsia spp. are caught on the rough-barked and small, spiny branches of Bucida spinosa; flat, ovoid seeds of Aechmea bracteata, which are disseminated by birds, germinate principally on Haematoxylum campechianum and Erythroxylum confusum, two rough-barked tree species, often in forks of major branches, and never on B. spinosa; the minute seeds of Schomburgkia tibicinis germinate generally on E. confusum, but also on Manilkara zapota and rarely on B. spinosa. Epiphyte association with non-ant arthropods is determined principally by the size and shape of the cavities. Most of the arthropods, including aquatic insects, are detritivores feeding on rotten debris which collects in the reservoirs of bromeliads. Some animals utilize epiphytes only as shelter. Epiphyte association with ants is largely correlated with the size and shape of the cavities. Intermediate steps between the "phytotelm' type and the "myrmecophytic' type were determined in the genus Tillandsia. The best rate of occupation by ants (96% of the ramets sheltered ants) was obtained by A. bracteata of the "phytotelm tank' type (reservoir in peripheric cavities, but also a waterproof central cavity), while the best rate of ant diversity was observed in T. bulbosa ("myrmecophytic' type; 26 ant species). Ants sheltered in the bromeliads protect host trees against defoliation by an undetermined chrysomelid beetle and the leaf-cutting ant Atta cephalotes. -Authors

dc:title: Decomposition and mass of woody detritus in the dry tropical forests of the northeastern Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico
dc:creator: Harmon M.
dc:description: The smallest mass of woody detritus was found in undisturbed stands: fine fractions (diameter <10 cm) averaged 4.7 Mg ha-1 and coarse fractions ranged between 13-38 Mg ha-1. The largest mass of fine woody detritus (32.2 Mg ha-1) was found in a hurricane-disturbed forest; the largest mass of coarse woody detritus (99.5 Mg ha-1) was found in stands disturbed by catastrophic fires. Decomposition rates varied greatly among species and diameters of branch segments. Over a 4 yr period, the decomposition rate constant for fine woody detritus ranged from 0.151-1.019 yr-1 and that for coarse woody detritus ranged from 0.008-0.615 yr-1. The half-life of woody detritus increased 33-fold (among pieces ranging 1-30 cm in diameter) for the most decay-resistant species (Manilkara zapota) but was relatively constant for the least decay-resistant species (Bursera simaruba). The wide range in decomposition rates indicates that the poor substrate quality of some species may override climatic (eg warm temperatures) and biotic (eg termites) factors favorable to rapid decomposition, leading to a substantial accumulation of woody detritus. -from Authors

dc:title: Sprouting after uprooting of canopy trees in the Atlantic rainforest of Brazil
dc:creator: Negrelle R.
dc:description: One hundred uprooted tres were evaluated in order to investigate the sprouting ability of different species and size clases, and to determine the extent of contribution of sprouting to gap closure. The large proportion (82%) of sample trees with live sprouts indicates that uprooting need not be associated with the death of the tree. Occurrence of sprouting, while independent of the diameter of the fallen trunk varied greatly among species. All the sampled trees found with sprouts fit the definition of non-pioneer species. Sprouts may compete successsfully with pioneer trees in the process of gap closure. -from Author

dc:title: Surface and buried seed banks from Krakatau, Indonesia: implications for the sterilization hypothesis
dc:creator: Whittaker R.J.
dc:description: Germination trials were carried out on surface and buried soil samples from the Krakatau islands; 36 species of seed plants germinated from the samples. The topsoil samples yielded the largest number of seedlings and species, and had a faster pace of germination. These samples were locally similar to each other but disharmonic with the extant vegetation. Seeds germinated both from samples buried by land crabs and from soils buried by layers of volcanic ash deposited 1930-33 and 1952-53. Eleven species of seed plants germinated from four samples buried 1930-33, indicating that these seeds survived burial by volcanic ash for 60 yr. -from Authors

dc:title: Within- and among-year variation in the levels of herbivory on the foliage of trees from a Mexican tropical deciduous forest
dc:creator: Filip V.
dc:description: Measurements of the levels of herbivore damage on the foliage of trees (16 species) were made for three consecutive years in the Chamela-dry forest. There was a marked similarity in the overall levels of damage despite the fact that there were considerable climatic differences among years and that some of the species showed at least one significant among-year difference. Mean leaf area loss of the studied species was 17%, a value higher than those commonly reported for tropical forests. An outstanding example of defoliation was that of Jatropha standleyi, with 73% leaf area eaten. During the early part of the rainy season the mean rate (0.352% leaf area eaten per day) was considerably higher than late in the season (0.097). Analyses of leaf nitrogen and water content early and late in the season indicated that these components of the nutritional quality of the foliage decrease as the season progresses. Discrete measurements of herbivory underestimated the true (long-term) values of leaf damage, probably by about half. The leaves of some species are eaten completely and thus missed in a one-time measurement. Another disadvantage of the discrete measurements is that information on the timing of damage is lost. -from Authors

dc:title: Hurricane Andrew and a Florida fig pollination mutualism: resilience of an obligate interaction
dc:creator: Bronstein J.
dc:description: Reports on the recovery of a Florida fig pollination mutualism devastated by Hurricane Andrew in August 1992. Damage to Ficus aurea included loss of all leaves and fruits and many branches, as well as the presumed local extinction of its pollinator Pegoscapus jimenezi. Within five months, however, fig flowering phenology and fig wasp abundance had recovered to near prehurricane levels. Unusual phenological traits of F. aurea may have aided in the rapid reestablishment of pollinator populations; also, the wasps may have previously underappreciated capacities for long distance movements. This study suggests that obligate interactions can be resilient to certain population-level catastrophes. -from Authors

dc:title: Avian consumers of cardon fruits (Stenocereus griseus: Cactaceae) on Margarita Island, Venezuela
dc:creator: Silvius K.
dc:description: The fruiting phenology and avian consumer set of cardon cactus fruits were observed on the semiarid Macanao Peninsula. The cardon population had two peak fruiting seasons (late May-early June and late August-early September) which correspond to the local rainy seasons, but many plants also produce low numbers of fruits throughout the year. Fruits were fed on continuously by a variety of consumers for several days while still attached to the plant. The avian consumer set included 14 species and was dominated by two species of parrots (Aratinga pertinax and the endangered Amazona barbadensis). Most of the avian consumers are omnivores that include variable amounts of fruit in their diet. Six of the bird species are seed predators, six act as seed dispersers, and two are neutral with respect to seed survival. Bats fed on the fruits but were unable to open the husks, and thus must rely on naturally dehisced fruits or fruits opened by psittacines. -from Author

dc:title: Ontogenetic changes in the diet of the rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) in a Neotropical Andean river
dc:creator: Segnini S.
dc:description: As studied in the Venezuelan Andes, immatures of Ephemeroptera, Trichoptera, and Diptera are the main components of the diet. Ephemeropterans are dominant in the diet of fishes in size classes <15 cm. Ephemeropterans and Trichopterans share their importance in number and biomass in the diet of trout in size classes >15 cm. Seasonal changes of total prey numbers and biomass in gut contents did not affect the proportional contribution of the different taxa within each size class. The infra-order taxa with most relative importance were the genera Baetodes, Baetis and Thraulodes (Ephemeroptera); Leptonema, Arctopshyche and Mortoniella (Trichoptera); the families Chironomidae, Blepharoceridae, and Tipulidae (Diptera) and terrestrial invertebrates. The trophic profiles of relative importance of preys differed significantly between size classes as a consequence of a different use of the drift and benthos fauna, and changes in prey selection within each food source. -from English summary

dc:title: Seed dispersal effectiveness by two bulbuls on Maesa lanceolata, an African montane forest tree
dc:creator: Graham C.
dc:description: Examined the effectiveness with which Andropadus latirostris and A. tephrolaemus (Pycnonotidae) dispersed seeds of a tropical pioneer forest tree, Maesa lanceolata (Myrsinaceae). Andropadus tephrolaemus and A. latirostris were the most common visitors to M. lanceolata in Nyungwe Forest, Rwanda, and accounted for 49.1% and 17.3% of all animal visits to the tree, resepctively. The mean (and standard deviation) residence times in the tree were 2.82 ± 1.65 min for A. tephrolaemus and 3.14 ± 1.70 min for A. latirostris. Individuals of both species are estimated 23 to 25 fruits per visit (3-20 seeds/fruit). Mean minimum seed passage times were 17.8 ± 1.93 min for A. tephrolaemus and 12.9 ± 0.80 min for A. latirostris. Seeds were viable after passing through the birds' gut. Most seeds passed through the gut within 20 min of the first defacation that contained seeds, and nearly all seeds passed within 80 min of ingestion. Mean time between defacations was 2.6 min for A. tephrolaemus and 2.2 min for A. latirostris. Frequency of return to the tree combined with the short tree residence times and defacation rates suggest that both species dispersed most seeds away from the parent tree; A. tephrolaemus may be a more important disperser for the tree because of its higher visitation rate. -from Authors

dc:title: Colonization and succession on Krakatau: an analysis of the guild of vining plants
dc:creator: Bush M.
dc:description: Changes in vine communities on the Krakatau Islands, Indonesia, during the last 111 yr provide an insight into colonization patterns in a regenerating tropical rain forest. In surveys of Krakatau between 1979-1992, 71 species of plants that may be described as having a vining growth habit are identified out of a total of 306 spermatophytes. Most vines on Krakatau are hermaphrodite, 24.6% are dioecious, and 3.7% are monoecious. All the vines are insect-pollinated, but the proportion of wind-, animal- and sea-dispersed vines varies according to the recent history of the islands. Rakata, the least disturbed island, carries the greatest diversity of vines and the highest proportion of sea-dispersed species. As with many island biotas the vine flora of Krakatau is a disharmonic subset of the mainland (SE Asian) pool and certain families, eg Annonaceae, Apocynaceae, Bignoniaceae, are relatively under- or unrepresented. -from Authors

dc:title: Tree damage and annual mortality in a montane forest in Monteverde, Costa Rica
dc:creator: Matelson T.
dc:description: Overall tree damage and mortality after four years was 15.9 trees ha-1yr-1, with >80% due to snapping of trunks and uprooting of whole trees. Of the 73 stems that snapped during the study interval, 20 regenerated live foliage from their broken stems. This resulted in an actual mortality rate of 12.7 trees ha-1yr-1, or 2.2%. Tree death occurred during all seasons of the year, but rates were highest during the wet season. Individuals of gap-colonizing species died at a higher rate than expected from their representation of the population. -from Authors

dc:title: Mangrove species distribution and propagule predation in Belize: an exception to the dominance-predation hypothesis
dc:creator: McKee K.
dc:description: Predation on mangrove propagules was studied to assess its impact on the intertidal distribution of Rhisophora mangle, Avicennia germinans and Laguncularia racemosa. Experiments conducted at Twin Cays in Belize showed that rates of predation (percent of propagules rendered nonviable in nine days) just after peak dispersal (December) were highest for A. germinans (60 ± 8%) and significantly lower for R. mangle (18 ± 5%) and L. racemosa (28 ± 9%), which were not significantly different. Rates varied seasonally, however, with highest losses of propagules at the beginning of dispersal (July). Major predators were the mangrove crabs, Goniopsis cruentata and Ucides cordatus. Comparison of predation rates in forest locations dominated by either R. mangle or A. germinans demonstrated that consumption of R. mangle propagules was highest in areas where it dominated the canopy and lowest where A. germinans was dominant. Predation also could not account for the infrequent occurrence of L. racemosa trees at Twin Cays. Only the predation pattern for A. germinans was consistent with intertidal dominance of trees. -from Author

dc:title: Comparative diets of obligate ant-following birds at a site in northern Bolivia
dc:creator: Chesser R.
dc:description: Army ants (Formicariidae: Dorylinae) are a distinctive feature of African and Neotropical rainforests. In Central and South America, swarms of Eciton burchelli and, less frequently, Labidus praedator, are attended by various species of antbirds (Formicariidae) and other birds. Stomach contents of five syntopic, obligate army-ant-following birds (Gymnopithys salvini, Rhegmatorhina melanosticta, Myrmeciza fortis, Phlegopsis nigromaculata, Dendrocincla merula) from a site in depto. Pando, Bolivia, were studied. The species are highly intra- and interspecificlly aggressive and are similar in foraging behavior. Diet composition and prey size differed little among species and were in general unrelated to trophic morphological characters or dominance status. Stomachs of dominant species, however, had greater numbers of prey items than stomachs of subdominants; this was the major dietary difference within this ant-following assemblage. The opportunistic resourse-use pattern of these species is similar to that of other groups of species that rely on temporally or spatially superabundant resources. -from Author

dc:title: Ecological observations of the lizard, Xenosaurus grandis in Cuautlapan, Veracruz, Mexico
dc:creator: Ballinger R.E.
dc:description: Xenosaurus grandis is locally abundant in crevices of boulders in perennial tropical forest. Individuals are solitary and highly aggressive when placed together. A diurnally active thermal conformer, body temperatures (average 22.7°C) correlate with both substrate and air temperatures and basking was not observed. Upper thermal limits (CTM) averaged 37.4°C. Food consisted primarily of insects by volume (Lepidoptera larvae and Orthoptera predominated), but occasional lizard prey are taken. -Authors

dc:title: Evidence for a role in seed dispersal by two tropical herbivorous turtles
dc:creator: Moll D.
dc:description: The capacity for seed dispersal by the aquatic Rhinoclemmys funerea and the terrestrial R. annulata was investigated at Tortuguero, Costa Rica. Defecated seeds of several riparian plant species from R. funerea feces and defecated seeds of several terrestrial plant species, mainly characteristic of treefall areas, from R. annulata feces germinated as well as uningested seeds with which they were compared. The R. funerea habit of regularly emerging from water to forage and defecate on river banks may contribute to the establishment of riparian species such as Dieffenbachia longispatha and Ficus glabrata. Rhinoclemmys annulata forages through tropical wet forest habitats, spending a disproportionate amount of time feeding in treefall areas. Its movement between these areas and defecation of seeds while foraging in them may contribute to the establishment of the distinctive flora of these small, disjunct habitats. -Authors

dc:title: Distribution, abundance and reproduction of Priacanthus arenatus Cuvier (Pisces: Priacanthidae) on the southern Gulf of Mexico continental shelf
dc:creator: Tapia-Garcia M.
dc:description: Priacanthus arenatus, a dominant species in the southern Gulf of Mexico, is distributed throughout the Campeche Sound area, generally in depths >36 m. It is not found in areas influenced by coastal discharges. Size of first maturity is 138 mm TL. Reproduction occurs in March (dry season) near Puerto Real inlet, around the 11 m isobath. Recruitment occurs in the area of reproduction from March-June. Adults and juveniles migrate to the outer shelf. Greatest abundance is observed around 36 m depth and abundance is correlated with the recruitment period. -English summary

dc:title: Folivory in fruit-eating bats, with new evidence from Artibeus jamaicensis (Chiroptera: Phyllostomidae)
dc:creator: Kunz T.
dc:description: Reviews leaf-eating by bats and presents new evidence for folivory by leaf fractionation for the neotropical bat Artibeus jamaicensis. Leaf-eating has been reported for at least 17 species of Old-World Megachiroptera and four species of New World Microchiroptera. Leaves eaten by bats include at least 44 species of plants represented by 23 different families. Plant families which account for the greatest species richness (numbers of species given in parentheses) include Leguminosae (12), Moraceae (4), and Solanaceae (4). Evidence for folivory by A. hamaicensis is based on captures of bats carrying leaves, and collections of whole and partially chewed leaves and discarded pellets recovered from beneath feeding roosts. Whole leaves carried into caves by A. jamaicensis and partially chewed, but discarded leaves included Erythrina poeppigiana, Ficus sp., and Calophyllum calaba, in decreasing order of frequency. Erythrina poeppigiana leaves are relatively high in protein (>19% dry-matter content) and low in fat (c1%). Observations that A. jamaicensis selects and chews leaves high in protein and rejects protein-poor, fibrous pellets, support the hypothesis that these bats extract liquid fractions which contain a reliable source of dietary protein. Liquid fractions derived from leaves may provide females with an important source of protein, especially during periods of pregnancy and lactation. -from Authors

dc:title: A comparison of Carex runssoroensis fens on Ruwenzori Mountains and Mount Elgon, Uganda
dc:creator: Rejmankova E.
dc:description: Carex runssoroensis, a tussock-forming sedge, is a dominant of peatlands endemic to the alpine zone of several E African mountains. Species composition, vertical structure, interspecific associations, plant biomass, plant and soil nutrient content, and redox potential were assessed in such fens from comparable altitudes on Ruwenzori Mountains and Mount Elgon. Fens from Mount Elgon exhibit higher species richness, more pronounced vertical structure, higher density of smaller tussocks, and lower content of nitrogen in the biomass. Ruwenzori fens are characterized by a smaller number of species, large Carex tussocks with higher nitrogen content and intervening hollows with a high proportion of mosses. The differences seem to be related to different climatic conditions: Mount Elgon is generally drier, with occasional fires burning even through peatlands; the Ruwenzori Mountains are more humid, resulting in almost constant flooding of some local peatlands. -Authors

dc:title: Biomass allocation by broad-leaf mahogany seedlings, Swietenia marophylla (King), in abandoned pasture and secondary dry forest in Guanacaste, Costa Rica
dc:creator: Gerhardt K.
dc:description: Biomass allocation, root/shoot (R/S) ratio, root surface area/leaf area, rooting depth and the root specialization (tap root/total system), were measured on 5, 13, 29 and 32 month-old seedlings. The field conditions were abandoned Hyparrhenia rufa pasture with mown and unmown grass and semi-evergreen secondary forest with normal and with reduced root competition under both thinned and unthinned forest canopy. Seedling biomass was lower in the secondary forest than in the pasture. Biomass was higher in mown than in unmown pasture. In the secondary forest, light availability rather than reduced root competition promoted biomass investment. R/S ratio did not increase by increasing light levels in the forest. A tendency of an increase in R/S ratio and root specialization was found with increasing seedling age, suggesting the importance of uptake and storage organs. -from Authors

dc:title: Effects of nectar consumption by the hummingbird flower mite Proctolaelaps kirmsei on nectar availability in Hamelia patens
dc:creator: Colwell R.
dc:description: Hummingbird flower mites consume nectar and pollen in the flowers they inhabit and are transported on hummingbirds. This study, conducted at La Selva, Costa Rica, measured the effects of Proctolaelaps kirmsei (Gamasina: Ascidae) and of pollinating hummingbirds on nectar volume of Hamelia patens (Rubiaceae). The mites consume, on average, 40% of the nectar produced by flowers, when hummingbirds are excluded. Mites and hummingbirds together consume 85% of the nectar. Individual trees in the study differed significantly and independently in both nectar production and mite population density. Results help establish hummingbird flower mites as significant plant parasites, especially considering their concomitant role as voracious consumers of pollen, as well as important competitors with hummingbirds for the nectar of their host plants. -from Author

dc:title: Production and cost of fruits and seeds in relation to inflorescence characteristics
dc:creator: Ramirez N.
dc:description: Levels of seed set and aborted seeds, ovules, and flowers and fruits were determined in 232 species of plants in relation to inflorescence type, inflorescence position, synchronization of anthesis within the inflorescence and the pollination unit, and the combination of these variables. The percentage of veriance between the levels of aborted ovules, aborted flowers and fruits, and seed set was significantly greater for inflorescence type than the other variables. Lowest levels of aborted seeds occur in spadices, as well as in axillary and terminal/axillary inflorescences. Lowest levels of aborted ovules and the highest levels of seed set occurred in terminal, capituliform inflorescences. Lowest levels of flower-fruit abortion were found in solitary flowers and in terminal, capituliform inflorescences, and in synchronous anthesis. There was a general tendency in this sample for low levels of abortion and high seed set to be associated with the low cost of fruits and individual seeds in inflorescence units. -from English summary

dc:title: Flowering and fruiting phenologies of the palm Acrocomia aculeata: patterns and consequences
dc:creator: Scariot A.
dc:description: Acrocomia aculeata was studied in the Distrito Federal, Brazil. Flowering began in August and extended into mid-December with the highest concentration of open inflorescences (>50% of the total) occurring from mid-October until mid-November. There was a significant correlation between flowering time and fruit set over the course of the reproductive seasons. The inflorescences that opened in October were those that produced highest fruit set, with fruit set mean of 25.4% (SD 20.9) in the first half and 28.9% (SD 24.4) in the second half of October. Overall, fruit set was less than 10.0%, although it ranged from 0-85.0%. Each infructescence produced c60 fruits, but it ranged from 0-271 fruits. Fruit fall occurred for 6-10 months, generally concentrated from October-January. -from Authors

dc:title: Defoliation of the mangrove Avicennia marina in Hong Kong: cause and consequences
dc:creator: Anderson C.
dc:description: In Hong Kong, Avicennia marina experiences intense herbivory every summer such that within three months all trees are defoliated. Rapid regeneration of the canopy follows, but reproductive output is severely impaired as defoliation coincides with flowering. The causal herbivore is the caterpillar of Nephopterix syntaractis (Lepidoptera: Pyralidae). Insecticide spraying reduced leaf damage and increased flower and propagule production. Tannin levels showed no increase with level of leaf damage but did differ between sprayed and control plots, reflecting a raised tannin content of regenerated leaves. -from Authors

dc:title: Spatial gradients and patch structure on two Puerto Rican landslides
dc:creator: Myster R.W.
dc:description: Total daily photosynthetic photon flux density was 50 times greater in the landslide compared to the surrounding forest, but similar between landslides. The red:far red ratio was homogeneous in the open areas of the landslides, but in areas covered by vegetation it was similar to those ratios found in the forest border. The soil had average extractable phosphorus of 0.108 g/m2 to 9cm depth. Nitrogen was 10% of average soil mass, carbon was 1.83% of average soil mass, and there was a 69% average moisture content. Seed rain averaged 31 seeds per trap with the seed pool showing an average of two seedlings per sample. Vesicular-arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi covered 7% of the average length of roots sampled, and the vegetation (dominated by species Cyathea arborea, Cecropia schreberiana, Miconia spp., and Nepsera acuatica) had two structural levels on average. For these factors, the strongest gradients was from the forest into the landslides from the side rather than from the top of the landslide to the bottom or between landslides. Evidence of distinct patches was found where patch structure was defined by levels of light, seed pool, fungi, vegetation, soil N, and soil C. Light, the key abiotic factor, showed very significant negative correlations with the key biotic factors of mycorrhizal fungi and vegetation, implying causal relationships. -from Authors
